Award.AbstractNarration:
The Conference on Econometrics and Mathematical Economics (CEME) holds a series of annual conferences on research issues in economic theory and statistical methods for the analysis of economic data. The purpose is to stimulate discussion and research in these areas, and to investigate the application of cutting edge mathematical, statistical, and computational techniques to economic research questions. The conferences focus on six topics, three in statistical methods and three in economic theory. Each topic conference meets once each year. The conferences are broadly interdisciplinary, including researchers from mathematics, operations research, and computer science. They also facilitate communication between academic scholars and government economists, since the statistical methods covered are important for macroeconomic policy.

Conference topics include Bayesian Econometrics, Forecasting, Microeconometrics, Time Series Analysis, Decentralization, and Mathematical Economics/General Equilibrium. There is a special series of econometrics sessions aimed at young scholars. Conference locations include universities around the United States.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant supported conference series in econometrics and economic theory. These conferences are all long-standing and important parts of the intellectual communities they represent. Over the long history of CEME, many fundamental advances in econometrics and economic theory were first presented during these workshops. These workshops have long fostered researchers working in both basic and applied areas of econometrics and economic theory.

Each year a conference was organized in each of the series in econometrics and economic theory: Time Series Econometrics, Young Econometricians Conference, Microeconometrics, Bayesian Inference in Econometrics and Statistics, Decentralization, and Mathematical Economics. Conferences were organized at a variety of different academic institutions and research institutions. Each conference series worked to foster interdisciplinary collaborations and cross-pollination. Participants included economists, statisticians, policy makers, computer scientists, political scientists, and other social scientists from both academic institutions, government, and private industries. Each conference has a long tradition of giving priority to junior scholars, and to fostering interactions between junior and senior scholars. They have all provided important opportunities for junior scholars to receive focused feedback on projects at critical junctures, as well as mentoring and networking opportunities.

Basic research in economic theory and econometrics provides the backbone for economics in academics, policy, and industry. Impacts of this project are as important and diverse as macroeconomic advice and forecasting for governments, theory and econometric methods for technology industry giants such as Google, Microsoft, Amazon and Ebay, school choice problems, and organ donation matching theory and practice.
